sections.heading: Core Function
sections.content:
へ indicates direction or orientation toward a destination.

Pronunciation: Written へ but pronounced "e"

東京へ行く toukyou e iku "go toward Tokyo"

sections.heading: Main Use: Direction
sections.content:
With movement verbs - indicates direction of movement:

学校へ行く - "go to/toward school" 日本へ来る - "come to Japan" 家へ帰る - "return home"

Common verbs: 行く, 来る, 帰る, 向かう

sections.heading: へ vs に
sections.content:
Both mark destination, but へ is more abstract:

東京に行く - "go to Tokyo" (specific destination) 東京へ行く - "go toward Tokyo" (direction)

In most cases, they're interchangeable for destination.

See: へ vs に Direction

sections.heading: へ Emphasizes Direction
sections.content:
When direction/path matters more than destination:

北へ向かう - "head north" 前へ進む - "advance forward" 上へ上がる - "go up"

children.heading: Static location (use に)
children.content: ✗ 部屋へいる ✓ 部屋にいる "be in the room"

children.heading: Action location (use で)
children.content: ✗ 図書館へ勉強する ✓ 図書館で勉強する "study at library"

children.heading: Time expressions
children.content: ✗ 三時へ ✓ 三時に "at 3 o'clock"

sections.heading: Common Patterns
sections.content: [Place]へ 行く/来る/帰る 学校へ行く - "go to school" [Direction]へ 向かう/進む 北へ向かう - "head north"

sections.heading: Formal/Literary Feel
sections.content:
へ sounds slightly more formal or literary than に:

Casual: 家に帰る Formal: 家へ帰る

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
✓ Indicates direction of movement ✓ Written へ, pronounced "e" ✓ More abstract than に ✓ Interchangeable with に for destination ✓ Slightly more formal/literary

Related:

に (ni) - Location/Direction へ vs に Direction で (de) - Location
